author: By David Colman
title: You Missed a Spot: How Not to Groom Your Dog During Lockdown
description: Clipping your dog’s coat is not exactly a fetch in the park.
content: As someone who often walks his dog — in this case an energetic white miniature schnauzer named Gogo — I occasionally find myself in a familiar conversation with other dog owners: where and how to groom the dog. Asking “where” implies that we go to a groomer to get the job done — but I don’t. Thus we proceed to how.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: A Man and Woman of Letters (Many of Them)
description: Logan Sachon and Matthew Davis met in 2008 while working together, but they didn’t become friends — correspondents, really — until years later. Love came later still.
content: Logan Sachon and Matthew Davis initially met in 2008, when she became an intern at an alternative weekly publication in Oregon; he was the news editor. They knew each other only casually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why Cocktail Hour Is Back
description: We need the ritual; we have the time. And during lockdown, it’s 5 o’clock everywhere.
content: “Is it too early to drink?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Coronavirus and the Price of Trump’s Delusions
description: A cult of personality is no match for a pandemic.
content: In an interview with The Washington Post on Tuesday, Dr. Robert Redfield, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, warned that a second wave of coronavirus infections this coming winter “will actually be even more difficult than the one we just went through,” because it will coincide with flu season. He also called the protests against stay-at-home orders “not helpful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ayendy Bonifacio
title: For Many Immigrants, an Even Greater Risk
description: I’m among the New Yorkers adjusting to working from home during the pandemic. But I’m the exception in my family.
content: I call my mother every afternoon to check in on her. She lives in a three-story Section 8 building in East New York, Brooklyn, in the apartment my siblings and I grew up in. Three of her neighbors died from Covid-19 in the last two weeks, and more than half of the families in her 12-unit building are sick. Through the walls she could hear the wails of the family who lost a loved one to the virus next door: “Don’t go! Please don’t leave us!” Another neighbor on the second floor, a middle-aged Ecuadorean man who lived with his elderly mother, died the day before Easter. The worst part, she said, is not being able to pay her respects in person, to say goodbye to the neighbors that over the years have become her family. I feel my stomach turn with guilt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: When a Coronavirus Lockdown Resembles an LSD Trip
description: All it took was a Dylan song to bring back memories of a summer in Alaska.
content: It was Day 8 of quarantine for me and my family. My son had returned from his semester abroad in Europe, and so we were all hunkered down in our Brooklyn house, cooking, eating, working together and listening to music. Dean, 20, was mostly in charge of the soundtrack and had just put on Bob Dylan’s “Tonight I’ll Be Staying Here With You” on Spotify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Trial Accuses Iraqi of Genocide in Killing of Yazidi Girl
description: The Frankfurt trial of the 27-year-old man accused of being an ISIS member is believed to be the first that carries the charge of genocide in relation to the Yazidis.
content: BERLIN — An Iraqi man accused of being an Islamic State terrorist has gone on trial in a high court in Frankfurt accused of genocide, human trafficking, and the torture and murder of a 5-year-old Yazidi girl he had held as a slave in Falluja, Iraq.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Jailed Huawei Workers Raised a Forbidden Subject: Iran
description: China arrested five former employees who had discussed the tech giant’s Iranian sales in a chat group, raising questions about its government ties.
content: The five men were all locked in disputes with their onetime employer, the Chinese technology giant Huawei. And they had all joined a group on the social app WeChat to organize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Is It Unethical to Ask My Roommate to Move Out Right Now?
description: It’s a tough time to be stuck with a roommate you don’t get along with.
content: Q: As my roommate and I follow New York’s stay-at-home orders, it’s painfully clear that I can no longer live with her. I’ve been looking at other apartments for a few weeks, and would like to move out as soon possible. I want to ask her to find her own place. Since I’m the sole leaseholder and we’re on a month-to-month rental agreement, this shouldn’t be a legal problem — but is it an ethical one? Is it fair to ask her to move out in the middle of this unusual situation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Farah Stockman and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Testing Remains Scarce as Governors Weigh Reopening States
description: In both red and blue states, governors, health departments and hospitals are finding innovative ways to cope, but still lack what experts say they need to track and contain outbreaks.
content: WASHINGTON — About a week after the first report of a Covid-19 case at a meatpacking plant in southwest Kansas in early April, the state’s governor, Laura Kelly, issued a pointed warning to President Trump: Without test kits to separate the well from the sick, a fast-moving outbreak could idle facilities that produce roughly one-quarter of the nation’s meat supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Boris Johnson Aide Attended Secretive U.K. Coronavirus Panel
description: Dominic Cummings, a major Brexit strategist, took part in Britain’s top scientific advisory group, but only to listen and offer help, the government said.
content: LONDON — The British government came under heightened pressure to disclose details about a secretive scientific advisory group after a report on Friday that a top political aide to Prime Minister Boris Johnson had taken part in the group’s meetings on the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Richard Hake, Longtime WNYC Radio Reporter and Host, Dies at 51
description: Mr. Hake produced and created live radio feature segments that focused on breaking news, culture and artistic sound portraits.
content: Richard Hake, a WNYC news host, reporter and producer for the past 28 years, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler and Michael H. Keller
title: Prescriptions Surged as Trump Praised Drugs in Coronavirus Fight
description: Prescriptions for two antimalarial drugs jumped by 46 times the average when the president promoted them on TV. There’s no proof they work against Covid-19.
content: It was at a midday briefing last month that President Trump first used the White House telecast to promote two antimalarial drugs in the fight against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Revelry on the Rooftops
description: Ashley Johnson and Eddie Zhang, both doctors, were married atop their apartment building in Philadelphia.
content: The drone heard on the rooftop of the Philadelphia apartment building where Dr. Ashley Johnson and Dr. Eddie Zhang live was not the kind created by the couple bemoaning their circumstances in the presence of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: The Apple Family’s Checking In on Zoom. You’re Invited, Too.
description: Richard Nelson’s new play, “What Do We Need to Talk About?” will be performed online, but live, restoring some of theater’s ephemerality.
content: Has anyone checked on the Apples? Do they have enough groceries? Are they working remotely? And what do they think about all those Manhattanites fleeing upstate?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: America Shouldn’t Have to Play by New York Rules
description: A national lockdown is bad medicine and worse politics.
content: In 1976, the artist Saul Steinberg drew a cover for The New Yorker — “View of the World from Ninth Avenue” — that became an instant classic. You know the one: Manhattan heavily in the foreground, the Hudson River, a brownish strip called “Jersey,” the rest of the America vaguely in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: ‘There Are No Viruses Here’: Leader of Belarus Scoffs at Lockdowns
description: Under the autocratic rule of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, Belarus has yet to impose any restrictions to slow the virus. No, everything is not fine.
content: MOSCOW — As he headed off the ice after playing a hockey game in an amateur tournament in late March, the leader of Belarus brushed aside reporters’ anxious questions about the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Health Officials Responding to Coronavirus Lacked Proper Gear and Training, Investigation Finds
description: Lawyers at the Department of Health and Human Services reported that protocols “temporarily broke down” when employees were working with people in quarantine.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal health employees without adequate protective gear or training interacted with Americans quarantined at a military installation in California for possible exposure to the coronavirus, the top lawyer at the Department of Health and Human Services concluded on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Rave Reviews at the Salon
description: Ellyna Larson and Kristi Bogart met at Ms. Bogart’s hair salon, after both had heard many good things about the other.
content: Ellyna Larson, a Federal agent with Homeland Security, walked through the front door of Eli’s Roots Hair Studio in Manassas, Va., in search of its owner, Kristi Bogart, a person of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fraying Nerves Dishearten City As Crisis Drags
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 25, 2020.
content: “This is the week where I feel like I have accepted this, and given up. My daily commute to the couch feels ‘normal.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Here’s How You Can Change Lives in the Pandemic
description: These causes will make great use of your money or your time.
content: Readers keep asking in this age of Covid-19: How can I help?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 25, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 25, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about how President Trump is spending his time in the White House misstated which position with the Federal Reserve that Mr. Trump had proposed for his outside economic adviser Stephen Moore. The president had chosen him to serve on the Federal Reserve Board, not to serve as its chairman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Health Officials Responding to Coronavirus Lacked Proper Gear and Training, Investigation Finds
description: Lawyers at the Department of Health and Human Services reported that protocols “temporarily broke down” when employees were working with people in quarantine.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal health employees without adequate protective gear or training interacted with Americans quarantined at a military installation in California for possible exposure to the coronavirus, the top lawyer at the Department of Health and Human Services concluded on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoff Ziezulewicz
title: Making Marines Without Making Them Sick
description: After a brief pause, Parris Island is once again taking Marine recruits, with some modifications to the grueling 13-week boot camp.
content: Like countless parents before her, LaTasha Webber worried about her 17-year-old after she signed an age waiver allowing him to enlist in the U.S. Marine Corps. Her son, Charlie Jennings, left for boot camp at Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island in South Carolina on Feb. 24, following in the footsteps of his father, who was also a Marine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: How to Live Stream Your Wedding
description: Thanks to video-streaming apps and services, couples who choose to get married while self-isolating can share their special moments with family and friends.
content: While social distancing and restrictions on travel and large gatherings have forced many couples to postpone their wedding celebrations, some are still choosing to marry and are inviting guests to witness their union from the comfort of their own homes via live video streams.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sheet-Pan Chicken With Jammy Tomatoes Forever
description: Pasta with garlicky spinach, curry chicken breasts and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Melissa Clark’s sheet-pan chicken with jammy tomatoes and pancetta (above); pasta with garlicky spinach and buttered pistachios; and roasted tomato and white bean stew. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson
title: ‘My World Is Shattering’: Foreign Students Stranded by Coronavirus
description: When the pandemic shuttered colleges, many international students had no idea where to live or whether they would ever be able to return to class.
content: When universities abruptly shut down last month because of the coronavirus pandemic, many students returned to their parents’ homes, distraught over having to give up their social lives and vital on-campus networking opportunities. Graduating seniors lost the chance to cross anything but a virtual commencement stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: Economic Freeze Cuts Remittances, a Lifeline for Migrants’ Families
description: Migrant workers globally send hundreds of billions of dollars home every year. The economic paralysis with the coronavirus pandemic threatens that.
content: ÁPORO, Mexico — The money would arrive like clockwork: $300 every couple of weeks, sent by her husband, a day laborer and undocumented immigrant living in Indianapolis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Black and Kirk Johnson
title: Serving Wings and a Prayer: It’s Back to Business for Fairbanks Restaurants
description: The Alaskan city 200 miles from the Arctic Circle was one of the first in the country to reopen restaurants after a long coronavirus shutdown.
content: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — Most of America now eats at the dining room table, or at the kitchen table, or on the couch, or in bed, or out on the front stoop. But in Alaska, at a place called the Roundup Steakhouse and Saloon, something remarkable happened in this age of infection.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Role of Restaurant Critics in an Uncertain Time
description: Sam Sifton, the food editor at The New York Times, spoke with the writers Pete Wells, Tejal Rao and Besha Rodell about how their jobs have changed.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Free Wedding in the Nick of Time
description: Maggie Moore and Brandon Baez married at Glencliff Manor, which offered to help couples whose weddings were upended because of the coronavirus.
content: Maggie Moore and Brandon Baez may be young, but waiting to get married until the world got a handle on the coronavirus was not in their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Fraying Nerves Dishearten City As Crisis Drags
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 25, 2020.
content: “This is the week where I feel like I have accepted this, and given up. My daily commute to the couch feels ‘normal.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: The Curious Incident of No Dog in the White House
description: What if Donald Trump had become the owner of a Goldendoodle?
content: It was Orson Welles’s idea, the Fala Speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Miller
title: An Obituary for an Extraordinary Ordinary Man
description: Cesar Quirumbay worked for some of America’s most prominent men. Very few blessed by his handiwork ever knew his name.
content: Cesar Quirumbay, who succumbed to Covid-19 on Monday morning at the age of 60, touched the lives of some of America’s most prominent actors, billionaires and businessmen. Yet very few people blessed by his touch ever knew his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Powell
title: The Day the Household Appliances Quit
description: They should have been pleased they were getting so much work. Instead they revolted.
content: The kettle was the first to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: US Journalists Seek to Help Colleagues Affected by Virus
description: Journalists from around the U.S. are finding ways to help their colleagues simply pay rent or buy groceries as they face lost or reduced paychecks because of layoffs and furloughs caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: OKLAHOMA CITY — Journalists from around the U.S. are finding ways to help their colleagues simply pay rent or buy groceries as they face lost or reduced paychecks because of layoffs and furloughs caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Family Over Flowers
description: Sarah Fagan and Ohmar Bogle opted for a scaled-down event at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan.
content: Sarah Fagan’s marriage to Ohmar Bogle on April 18 at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Manhattan went on as planned, though the coronavirus forced their wedding to become “a very, very, very, very scaled-down event,” said the groom, who was among a group of nine people at the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Rave Reviews at the Salon
description: Ellyna Larson and Kristi Bogart met at Ms. Bogart’s hair salon, after both had heard many good things about the other.
content: Ellyna Larson, a Federal agent with Homeland Security, walked through the front door of Eli’s Roots Hair Studio in Manassas, Va., in search of its owner, Kristi Bogart, a person of interest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Amid the Coronavirus Crisis, Heart and Stroke Patients Go Missing
description: Emergency physicians are seeing declines in the number of patients arriving with cardiac problems. Some say they were afraid to go to the hospital.
content: Bishnu Virachan was a bicycle deliveryman for a grocery store in Queens. With New York City locked down, he was busier than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vindu Goel
title: Boeing Terminates $4.2 Billion Deal to Buy Stake in Embraer Unit
description: The U.S. aviation giant, struggling with the 737 Max crisis and canceled orders, no longer wants Embraer’s commercial jet business.
content: Boeing, which is contending with the economic fallout from the pandemic and the grounding of its 737 Max jets, said Saturday that it had terminated an agreement to buy 80 percent of Embraer’s commercial jet business for $4.2 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: Nervous Republicans See Trump Sinking, and Taking Senate With Him
description: The election is still six months away, but a rash of ominous new polls and the president’s erratic briefings have the G.O.P. worried about a Democratic takeover.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s erratic handling of the coronavirus outbreak, the worsening economy and a cascade of ominous public and private polling have Republicans increasingly nervous that they are at risk of losing the presidency and the Senate if Mr. Trump does not put the nation on a radically improved course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns, Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: A Candidate in Isolation: Inside Joe Biden’s Cloistered Campaign
description: Walled off from voters in a distinctive kind of lockdown, Mr. Biden has developed a routine, of sorts, as he seeks the presidency from his basement.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. usually rises before 8 a.m. at his home in Wilmington, Del., and starts his day with a workout in an upstairs gym that contains a Peloton bike, weights and a treadmill. He often enjoys a protein shake for breakfast and puts on a suit or blazer much of the time. In the evenings, he and his wife, Jill, sit down together for dinner, a ritual that was absent for much of the last frenzied year on the campaign trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How to Ask a College for More Financial Aid
description: It’s an admissions season unlike any other, with uncertainty for students and their families — and the colleges that want to get them in the door.
content: It is rarely easy to summon the will to ask for help, especially if you’re seeking more financial aid from what you believe to be your first-choice college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bad Education’ and ‘Hustlers’
description: Real-life scandals are dramatized in HBO’s “Bad Education” and the Jennifer Lopez crime drama “Hustlers.”
content: BAD EDUCATION (2020) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Hugh Jackman and Allison Janney star in this dark comedy-drama, a cross between “Election” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.” The movie, directed by Cory Finley (“Thoroughbreds”), reimagines a multi-million-dollar embezzlement scandal that rocked a high school on Long Island in 2004. The mastermind behind the scheme is Frank Tassone (Jackman), the superintendent of the school district, who wins over parents and students alike with his good-natured charm. His machination lasts years, and it slowly starts to crumble only after he encourages a student journalist (Geraldine Viswanathan) to dig deeper into a puff piece she’s working on. (Big mistake.) In his review for The New York Times, Ben Kenigsberg wrote that Jackman steals the show. His role is “a plum part” and “a chance for the actor to channel his charisma toward dark, mischievous ends.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The N.F.L. Draft Adds More Stars to the Cool Kids’ Conference
description: The N.F.L. is a quarterback’s league and one conference has the edge in exciting young stars.
content: The A.F.C. was already where the fresh-faced cool kids hung out: Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, Deshaun Watson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Scene 1: City Hall. Scene 2: Rooftop Overlooking City.
description: Amanda Jane Cooper and Andrew Bell met at church, and then married in New York when the coronavirus seemed likely to foil their wedding plans.
content: Amanda Jane Cooper was new to New York when she first attended the Church of the City New York, to which a friend had referred her. She is an actor and was in the starring role of Glinda in “Wicked” at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jia Lynn Yang
title: Who Belongs In America?
description: For many, the recent harassment of Asian-Americans has been a stunning reminder that your face can still mark you as foreign.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: American Exceptionalism on Trial
description: Politicians extol it. Scholars debate it. The past decade has battered it. Will the coronavirus crisis finish off this country’s golden view of itself?
content: “It can’t happen here” is an enduring refrain in American culture, a reflection of the idea — whether invoked ironically or in earnest — that the United States has a special destiny, and stands apart from the forces shaping the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Americans Stranded Abroad Weigh Options; Spain Announces Easing of Restrictions
description: Belarus, led by a virus-denying autocrat, has imposed no lockdowns. Brazil’s leader, who has played down the virus, faces an uncertain future.
content: Many Americans who had assumed they could stay overseas till the pandemic ebbed now face an unnerving choice: either prepare for the possibility of being infected and treated in foreign hospitals, or risk infection on the way back to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Tim Duncan to Springfield? Take It to the Bank
description: During his Hall of Fame career, Duncan was called the Big Fundamental largely because of his signature shots off the backboard, which were as mundane as they were effective.
content: On one of his recent podcast episodes, C.J. McCollum of the Portland Trail Blazers engaged in a discussion about the five most unstoppable moves in N.B.A. history. Allen Iverson’s crossover dribble, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar’s sky hook, Manu Ginobili’s Eurostep, Hakeem Olajuwon’s “Dream Shake” and, of course, Michael Jordan’s fadeaway jumper were all featured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jia Lynn Yang
title: Who Belongs In America?
description: For many, the recent harassment of Asian-Americans has been a stunning reminder that your face can still mark you as foreign.
content: [Race affects our lives in countless ways. To read more provocative stories on race from The Times, sign up here for our weekly Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Graham Bowley
title: Live Nation Closes Gap in Refund Policy after Fan Complaints
description: The company, which operates Ticketmaster, will now allow refunds for the thousands of concerts that have yet to be rescheduled.
content: Live Nation Entertainment, the biggest power in the concert industry, closed a gap in its ticket refund policy on Friday, after weeks of criticism that the company, and its Ticketmaster subsidiary, were not returning hundreds of millions of dollars that fans had spent on concerts postponed by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Bad Education’ and ‘Hustlers’
description: Real-life scandals are dramatized in HBO’s “Bad Education” and the Jennifer Lopez crime drama “Hustlers.”
content: BAD EDUCATION (2020) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. Hugh Jackman and Allison Janney star in this dark comedy-drama, a cross between “Election” and “The Wolf of Wall Street.” The movie, directed by Cory Finley (“Thoroughbreds”), reimagines a multi-million-dollar embezzlement scandal that rocked a high school on Long Island in 2004. The mastermind behind the scheme is Frank Tassone (Jackman), the superintendent of the school district, who wins over parents and students alike with his good-natured charm. His machination lasts years, and it slowly starts to crumble only after he encourages a student journalist (Geraldine Viswanathan) to dig deeper into a puff piece she’s working on. (Big mistake.) In his review for The New York Times, Ben Kenigsberg wrote that Jackman steals the show. His role is “a plum part” and “a chance for the actor to channel his charisma toward dark, mischievous ends.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The N.F.L. Draft Adds More Stars to the Cool Kids’ Conference
description: The N.F.L. is a quarterback’s league and one conference has the edge in exciting young stars.
content: The A.F.C. was already where the fresh-faced cool kids hung out: Patrick Mahomes, Lamar Jackson, Deshaun Watson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Scene 1: City Hall. Scene 2: Rooftop Overlooking City.
description: Amanda Jane Cooper and Andrew Bell met at church, and then married in New York when the coronavirus seemed likely to foil their wedding plans.
content: Amanda Jane Cooper was new to New York when she first attended the Church of the City New York, to which a friend had referred her. She is an actor and was in the starring role of Glinda in “Wicked” at the time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: American Exceptionalism on Trial
description: Politicians extol it. Scholars debate it. The past decade has battered it. Will the coronavirus crisis finish off this country’s golden view of itself?
content: “It can’t happen here” is an enduring refrain in American culture, a reflection of the idea — whether invoked ironically or in earnest — that the United States has a special destiny, and stands apart from the forces shaping the rest of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yi-Zheng Lian
title: China Has a Post-Pandemic Dream for Hong Kong
description: Anticipating a hostile world, Beijing feels that it needs to control the city absolutely.
content: The coronavirus epidemic may have momentarily dampened the pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, but not the repression. The Chinese authorities in Beijing, after threatening to impose “complete-control governance” (全面管治) over the city in recent years, have in the course of a week taken several major steps toward that goal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: We Need Herd Immunity From Trump and the Coronavirus
description: It will take more care than the president is currently demonstrating to loosen restrictions but still protect the vulnerable.
content: With each passing day it becomes more obvious how unlucky we are that one of the worst crises in American history coincides with Donald Trump’s presidency. To get out of this crisis with the least loss of life and least damage to our economy, we need a president who can steer a science-based, nonpartisan debate through the hellish ethical, economic and environmental trade-offs we have to make.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Americans Stranded Abroad Weigh Options; Spain Announces Easing of Restrictions
description: Belarus, led by a virus-denying autocrat, has imposed no lockdowns. Brazil’s leader, who has played down the virus, faces an uncertain future.
content: Many Americans who had assumed they could stay overseas till the pandemic ebbed now face an unnerving choice: either prepare for the possibility of being infected and treated in foreign hospitals, or risk infection on the way back to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Americans Abroad Ask Whether to Stay, and Risk Infection, or Fly Home, and Risk Infection
description: As virus cases increase, Americans overseas wonder if it is better to take a commercial flight back to the United States — even if it means interacting with people who could infect them.
content: WASHINGTON — The travel plan was as exhausting as it was risky for the 77-year-old cancer survivor wondering how to leave self-isolation in Ecuador and return home to New Hampshire without catching the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cuomo Announces Expanded Virus Testing in New York
description: In addition to allowing all pharmacies in the state to administer tests, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced new antibody testing for front-line health care workers at four New York City hospitals.
content: New Yorkers anxious to learn if they have the coronavirus will soon be able to get tested at any local pharmacy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: In a Crowded City, Leaders Struggle to Separate the Sick From the Well
description: Chelsea, Mass., has an infection rate higher than any other community in the state. With families in cramped housing, it is difficult to contain the spread.
content: CHELSEA, Mass. — Paul Nowicki, the director of operations for the housing authority in this small, crowded immigrant city, walked the halls of the Buckley Apartments last week in a plastic face shield and white gown, trying to stop an invisible predator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Sergey Ponomarev
title: Bored Russians Posted Silly Art Parodies. The World Has Joined In.
description: Frozen dumplings as skulls and A/C ducts as fashion accessories. A Facebook group for art re-enactors has gained 540,000 followers across the locked-down globe.
content: MOSCOW — Under lockdown, the banal melds with the sublime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Jasmin Lavoie
title: Bertha Laforest, Canadian Nun Who Found Refuge in Her Convent, Dies At 94
description: Sister Laforest was one of at least 36 of the 47 nuns in her Quebec convent to become infected with the coronavirus. Three others have died.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Turn, Turn, Turn
description: Royce Ferguson whips around the bend with a smashing debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It’s so fun when someone roars into the crossworld out of nowhere with an inspired puzzle like this! According to Will Shortz’s print introduction, Royce Ferguson is an American living in London, who got the idea for this puzzle while in Switzerland, “a nation known for its 47-Acrosses.” Mr. Ferguson notes that he solves both his weekend puzzles on paper on Saturday because of the International New York Times publishing schedule, so he’s a binger and a paper solver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: F.T.C. Warns 10 Companies About Virus-Related Health and Business Claims
description: In warning letters sent on Friday, the agency cracked down for the first time on claims about earnings opportunities amid the pandemic.
content: The Federal Trade Commission has warned 10 companies to stop making health claims about treating and preventing the coronavirus or pitching business opportunities amid the pandemic, the agency announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Suggests Daily Briefings No Longer Worth His Time as White House Considers Replacing Health Secretary
description: States move to reopen as the U.S. nears a sobering 50,000 deaths from the virus. U.S. scientists join the World Health Organization in calling for better antibody tests.
content: This briefing has ended. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus pandemic here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Vivian Yee
title: Tux, Gown, Masks: Arab Couples Scramble to Marry During a Pandemic
description: Undeterred by the coronavirus, couples across the Middle East are pressing ahead with scaled-back weddings. The authorities aren’t always thrilled.
content: CAIRO — Carfuls of hooting men careened through the half-empty streets of Cairo, then skidded to a halt on Qasr el Nil, the most famous bridge over the Nile. A newly married couple leapt out, trailed by festive relatives, hoping for a coveted photo at an iconic beauty spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: The Paramedics Couldn’t Find Lysol. They Turned to Their Congressman.
description: “They don’t know who else to come to.” Members of Congress have overhauled their offices to answer increasingly desperate calls from constituents in search of a lifeline and unsure of who can help.
content: WASHINGTON — The messages clog their offices’ phone lines and inboxes by the thousands, each a snapshot of someone’s lived nightmare — the wife whose husband is on a ventilator and getting worse by the day, the small-business owner who desperately needs a loan, the paramedic who wants disinfectant to clean his ambulance between shuttling the ill to the hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Air France-KLM Gets €10 Billion Bailout as Coronavirus Hits Travel
description: It is the third multibillion-euro lifeline extended this past week by the French government to companies battered by the pandemic.
content: PARIS — France and the Netherlands will provide an unprecedented taxpayer-funded bailout of 10 billion euros, about $10.8 billion, to salvage Air France-KLM as the fallout of the coronavirus on the travel industry exacts a devastating toll on global air carriers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: How to Save Summer 2020
description: A balance can be found to be both safe and outdoors.
content: One evening in mid-March, looking to scratch a creative and social itch, the photographer John Martin texted his neighbors in Grosse Pointe Park, Mich., to come outside for a socially distanced photo shoot. The street, he said, seemed to light up with cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Post Malone Covering Nirvana for Virus Relief? Bring on the ‘Bleach’
description: The woozy-singing pop superstar performed a faithful set of covers to raise money for the W.H.O.’s Covid-19 Solidarity Response Fund, and won over the band’s bassist, Krist Novoselic.
content: On Wednesday, in a brief, vague video teaser, the immensely popular rap-adjacent superstar Post Malone announced that something called the “Post Malone Nirvana Tribute Livestream” would be happening on his YouTube channel on Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Michael Cogswell, 66, Dies; Sustained Louis Armstrong’s Legacy
description: He turned the jazz giant’s trove of memorabilia into a scholarly archive and created a popular museum at Armstrong’s house in Queens.
content: Michael Cogswell, who turned Louis Armstrong’s trove of memorabilia into a scholarly archive and transformed the joyful trumpeter’s two-bedroom brick house in Queens into a popular museum, died on April 20 in Manhattan. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Building a Better, Fairer Nation
description: Readers discuss issues of inequality raised by the “The America We Need” series of articles.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: March, April, May: City’s Mood Darkens as Crisis Feels Endless
description: With no clues about when the pandemic might subside, short-term discomfort is becoming long-term despair: “I feel like I have accepted this, and given up.”
content: A walk in the park brings tense flare-ups: Back off, you’re too close. Oh really? Then stay home. A loud neighbor, once a fleeting annoyance of urban life, is cause for complaint to the city. Wake at noon, still tired. The city’s can-do resilience has given way to resignation and random tears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Reopening Has Begun. No One Is Sure What Happens Next.
description: The heated debate over when to restart the economy has obscured an issue that could prove just as thorny: How to do it.
content: The economy shut down almost overnight. It won’t start back up that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl, Robin Stein, Drew Jordan, Ainara Tiefenthäler and David Botti
title: Where Is Kim Jong-un? How Experts Track North Korea’s Leader
description: Rumors are swirling about Kim Jong-un’s location and health. These North Korea experts showed us how they collect information about his secretive regime.
content: Rumors are swirling about Kim Jong-un’s location and health. These North Korea experts showed us how they collect information about his secretive regime.
source.name: The New York Times
